heading.content: You can name and compare the two human sex cells.

items.content:
You know the parts and functions of the reproductive organs. The reproductive organs produce sex cells. They form an organ system called the reproductive system. Now we are going to learn about the sex cells.

The female sex cell

In females, the ovaries contain small, undeveloped egg cells. Once every 28-32 days, an egg cell from one ovary becomes mature. It is released into the oviduct (sometimes called the Fallopian tube).

Figure 1, Ovulation is the release of an egg cell and happens every 28-32 days.

The oviduct is lined with cilia that sweep the egg cell towards the uterus. The uterus is where the baby will develop. It has strong, muscular walls and a soft lining.

Figure 2, A human egg cell with labeled parts. A sperm cell is shown for scale.

The egg cell is perfectly built for its job. It needs to recieve the human sperm cell and make sure only one enters. For this purpose it has a jelly coat arounds its cell membrane. The jelly coat hardens after a single sperm cell has entered. This way no more than one sperm is able to enter. Also it is very big compared to the sperm, it has a lot of cytoplasm. This way the egg cell can devide a couple of times on the way to the uterus wall, speeding up the development of the embryo.

The male sex cell

Males make sperm cells in their testes. The testes are held outside the body in a bag of skin called the scrotum. Their position helps to keep the sperm cells at the right temperature to develop properly.

Figure 3, The path human semen takes from the testis to the penis.

When sperm cells are released from the testes they travel up the sperm ducts, where special fluids are added from glands. The fluids give the sperm cells energy. Together the sperm cells and the fluids are called semen The semen leaves through the urethra. This tube also carries urine from the bladder, but never at the same time as semen.

Figure 4, A human sperm cell with labeled parts.

A human sperm cell might look simple, but it actually is build perfectly for its job! It's job is to deliver genetic material to the female egg cell. The tail allows it to swim. There is very little cytoplasm so that the cell can have a thin streamlined shape. The nucleus contains half the genetic material needed to make a human being. The tip of the head (acrosome) contains chemicals that attack the jelly coat of the egg cell. This allows the sperm cell to burrow inside.

items.caption: Fertilisation in sea urchins. If you look closely, you can see the jelly coat growing and hardening. This happens after the first sperm has entered. It stops secondary sperm from entering (this would interfere with the development of the embryo).

items.content:
Answer these questions in your notebook:

1) Where are human egg cells produced?

2) Where are human egg cells fertilized?

3) Name the four parts of an egg cell.

4) Why can't more than one sperm cell enter the egg cell?

5) Why is the egg cell so big compared to the sperm cell?

6) Where are human sperm cells produced?

7) What is in semen?

8) List four parts of sperm cells.

9) What is the function of the acrosome?

ovaries - this is where the egg cells are produced and released from

oviduct - tube running from the ovary to the uterus (also called Fallopian tube)

nucleus - a large part of a cell that contains the genetic material

jelly coat - a jelly like layer that surrounds the egg cell

testes - this is where the sperm cells are produced

scrotum - a sac of skin that holds the testes

vas deferens - tube that carries the sperm to the urethra, fluids are added in the vas deferens to make semen

urethra - urine and semen travel through this tube to (and through) the penis

acrosome - the tip of the head of the sperm cell, it contains chemicals that attack the jelly coat of the egg cell. This allows the sperm cell to burrow inside.
